p: We estimated the partial correlation coefficient between body mass and the year of collection (r year) for each species separately, through conventional linear regression models, using (absolute) latitude, longitude, and sex as covariates in the models. Then, we evaluated differences in r year between taxonomic groups (i.e., birds or mammals) and species habitats (i.e., aquatic or terrestrial) using a two-way ANOVA. The correlation coefficient between body mass and the year of collection (r year) was not correlated with sample size, species body mass, or species distribution, but was correlated with the length of the time series (r = 0.36, P = 0.02). Hence, in addition to the ANOVA, we also ran an ANCOVA using the length of time series as a covariate. In these analyses, we used the Kolmogorov-Smirnov test to assess normality, Levene’s test to assess homogeneity of variance, and (in ANCOVA) a parallelism test to assess the interaction between factors and the covariate. All these analyses were done with Statistica (version 8.0) software [ 21], with statistical significance established at the α = 0.05 level.
